**Xi Jinping** (Chinese: 习近平; pinyin: *Xí Jìnpíng*, pronounced [ɕǐ tɕîn.pʰǐŋ];[a] born 15 June 1953) is a Chinese politician who has been serving as the general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) and chairman of the Central Military Commission (CMC), and thus as the paramount leader of China, since 2012. Xi has also served as the president of the People's Republic of China (PRC) since 2013. He belongs to the fifth generation of Chinese leadership.

He and the CCP Central Committee passed a "historical resolution" in November 2021, the third such resolution after Mao Zedong and Deng Xiaoping. In October 2022, Xi secured a third term as CCP General Secretary, the second leader of the CCP to do so after Mao, and in March 2023 was reelected state president for a third term, the first head of state to be so.




## Early life and education[edit]


Xi Jinping was born in Beijing on 15 June 1953,[2] the third child of Xi Zhongxun and his second wife Qi Xin. After the founding of the PRC in 1949, Xi's father held a series of posts, including Party propaganda chief, vice-premier, and vice chairperson of the National People's Congress.[3] Xi had two older sisters, Qiaoqiao, born in 1949 and An'an (安安; *Ān'ān*), born in 1952.[4][5] Xi's father was from Fuping County, Shaanxi, and Xi could further trace his patrilineal descent from Xiying in Dengzhou, Henan.[6][*unreliable source?*]

Throughout Hu's tenure, China's influence in Africa, Latin America, and other developing regions increased.


Hu possessed a modest and reserved leadership style. His tenure was characterized by collective leadership and consensus-based rule.[2] These traits made Hu a rather enigmatic figure in the public eye. His administration was known for its focus more on technocratic competence than persona.[3] At the end of his tenure after ten years in office, Hu won praise for retiring voluntarily from all positions. He was succeeded by Xi Jinping. Following the death of his predecessor Jiang Zemin, Hu is the only living former paramount leader of the People's Republic of China.

### Power transition of Xi Jinping[edit]

On 15 November 2012, immediately after the 18th CCP National Congress, Xi was elected to the posts of general secretary of the CCP and chairman of the CMC by the 18th Central Committee, succeeding Hu.[57] On 14 March 2013, he was succeeded by Xi as president.[58]



## After retirement[edit]


Since his retirement, Hu has kept a low-profile, rarely making public appearances. In September 2013, Hu visited an ancestral family home in Huangshan, Anhui, though the trip was not covered by state media.[59] In April 2014, he made an appearance in Hunan, visiting Hunan University and other historical sites.[60] He attended the 19th CCP National Congress in October 2017.[61] He also attended the 70th anniversary of the People's Republic of China in October 2019, and the 100th anniversary of the Chinese Communist Party in July 2021.[62]

## Leadership[edit]


See also: Hu–Wen Administration

### Succeeded Jiang Zemin[edit]


![](image)Hu Jintao speech as General Secretary of the Communist Party of China and President of China
On 15 November 2002, after the 16th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party, a new Hu Jintao-led Politburo nominally succeeded Jiang's, while Hu became the CCP general secretary, effectively making him the paramount leader. Additionally, Wen Jiabao became the premier. However, Jiang was re-elected to the post of chairman of the Central Military Commission, the top military body, despite Hu taking over as the general secretary.[32] Jiang resigned as CMC chairman in September 2004, his last official post. Following Jiang's stepping-down, Hu had officially taken on the three institutions in the People's Republic of China where power lie; the party, the state, as well as the military.

Based on the search results, I can tell you that Hu Jintao was born on December 21, 1942, in Jiangyan, Jiangsu province, China. He served as the paramount leader of China from 2002 to 2012, holding several key positions:

His leadership style was characterized as modest and reserved, with a focus on collective leadership and consensus-based rule. He was known more for his technocratic competence than his personality. After his ten years in office, he was succeeded by Xi Jinping and voluntarily retired from all positions, which was praised at the time.

Since his retirement, Hu has maintained a low profile, making only rare public appearances. Following the death of his predecessor Jiang Zemin, he is currently the only living former paramount leader of the People's Republic of China.

His wife is Liu Yongqing, and he has a son named Hu Haifeng. Before becoming the paramount leader, he held various important positions including:
- First Secretary of the Communist Youth League (1984-1985)
- Party Committee Secretary of Guizhou province (1985-1988)
- Party Committee Secretary of Tibet Autonomous Region (1988-1992)
- Vice President of China (1998-2003)

In October 2022, Xi secured a third term as CCP General Secretary, the second leader of the CCP to do so after Mao, and in March 2023 was reelected state president for a third term, the first head of state to be so.




## Early life and education[edit]


Xi Jinping was born in Beijing on 15 June 1953,[2] the third child of Xi Zhongxun and his second wife Qi Xin. After the founding of the PRC in 1949, Xi's father held a series of posts, including Party propaganda chief, vice-premier, and vice chairperson of the National People's Congress.[3] Xi had two older sisters, Qiaoqiao, born in 1949 and An'an (安安; *Ān'ān*), born in 1952.[4][5] Xi's father was from Fuping County, Shaanxi, and Xi could further trace his patrilineal descent from Xiying in Dengzhou, Henan.[6][*unreliable source?*]

<fragment>
Throughout Hu's tenure, China's influence in Africa, Latin America, and other developing regions increased.


Hu possessed a modest and reserved leadership style. His tenure was characterized by collective leadership and consensus-based rule.[2] These traits made Hu a rather enigmatic figure in the public eye. His administration was known for its focus more on technocratic competence than persona.[3] At the end of his tenure after ten years in office, Hu won praise for retiring voluntarily from all positions. He was succeeded by Xi Jinping. Following the death of his predecessor Jiang Zemin, Hu is the only living former paramount leader of the People's Republic of China.

## Leadership[edit]


See also: Hu–Wen Administration

### Succeeded Jiang Zemin[edit]


![](image)Hu Jintao speech as General Secretary of the Communist Party of China and President of China
On 15 November 2002, after the 16th National Congress of the Chinese Communist Party, a new Hu Jintao-led Politburo nominally succeeded Jiang's, while Hu became the CCP general secretary, effectively making him the paramount leader. Additionally, Wen Jiabao became the premier. However, Jiang was re-elected to the post of chairman of the Central Military Commission, the top military body, despite Hu taking over as the general secretary.[32] Jiang resigned as CMC chairman in September 2004, his last official post. Following Jiang's stepping-down, Hu had officially taken on the three institutions in the People's Republic of China where power lie; the party, the state, as well as the military.

msg.name: search

msg.content:
Based on the search results, here are the key details about Hu Jintao:

1. Political Career:
- Served as General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party (2002-2012)
- President of the People's Republic of China (2003-2013)
- Chairman of the Central Military Commission (2004-2012 for Party Commission, 2005-2013 for State Commission)
- Prior to becoming paramount leader, he served as Vice President (1998-2003) and held various other positions

2. Personal Information:
- Born: December 21, 1942 (currently 81 years old)
- Birthplace: Taizhou, Jiangsu, China
- Education: Graduated from Tsinghua University with a degree in hydraulic engineering
- Family: Married to Liu Yongqing; has two children - Hu Haifeng and Hu Haiqing

3. Leadership Style and Legacy:
- Known for his modest and reserved leadership style
- His tenure was characterized by collective leadership and consensus-based rule
- Focused more on technocratic competence than personal charisma
- Notable for voluntarily retiring from all positions at the end of his tenure
- During his leadership, China's influence increased in Africa, Latin America, and other developing regions

4. Succession:
- Succeeded Jiang Zemin as China's paramount leader
- Was succeeded by Xi Jinping
- Following Jiang Zemin's death, he is currently the only living former paramount leader of the People's Republic of China

5. Key Policies and Theories:
- Promoted concepts such as "China's peaceful rise"
- Advocated for a "Harmonious Society"
- Developed the "Scientific Outlook on Development"
- Emphasized the "Eight Honors and Eight Shames"

Ask a capable helper for help looking up a piece of information or performing an action.
Do not simply repeat what the user said as instructions.
You should use this to break up complex user queries into multiple simpler steps.
NOTE: Helpers cannot see previous parts of your conversation.

Xi has also served as the president of the People's Republic of China (PRC) since 2013. He belongs to the fifth generation of Chinese leadership.

msg.name: search

msg.content:
Based on the Wikipedia search results, here are the key details about Hu Jintao:

1. Political Career:
- Served as General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party (2002-2012)
- President of the People's Republic of China (2003-2013)
- Chairman of the Central Military Commission (2004-2012/2013)
- Prior to leadership, held positions including Vice President (1998-2003), Party Secretary of Tibet (1988-1992), and First Secretary of Communist Youth League (1984-1985)

2. Personal Information:
- Born: December 21, 1942 in Taizhou, Jiangsu, China
- Age: 81
- Education: Graduated from Tsinghua University with a degree in hydraulic engineering
- Family: Married to Liu Yongqing; has two children - Hu Haifeng and Hu Haiqing

3. Leadership:
- Succeeded Jiang Zemin as China's paramount leader
- Was succeeded by current leader Xi Jinping
- Led China during a period of significant economic growth
- Known for policies including "China's peaceful rise," "Harmonious Society," and "Scientific Outlook on Development"

4. Recent Events:
- Made a rare public appearance in 2022 at Jiang Zemin's funeral ceremony
- Was notably led out of the 20th Party Congress in October 2022, which garnered international attention

5. Legacy:
- Represented the fourth generation of Chinese leadership
- Known for his relatively low-key leadership style
- Focused on balanced development and social harmony during his tenure
- Oversaw China's continued economic rise and increasing global influence

msg.name: delegate

msg.content:
Let me compile the information I have found through these searches:

The birthplaces of the last five Presidents of the People's Republic of China are:

1. Xi Jinping - Born in Beijing (though he grew up in Fuping County, Shaanxi Province)
2. Hu Jintao - Born in Taizhou, Jiangsu Province
3. Jiang Zemin - Born in Yangzhou, Jiangsu Province
4. Yang Shangkun - Born in Shuangjiang, Tongnan County, Sichuan Province
5. Li Xiannian - Born in Hong'an County, Hubei Province

These leaders served consecutively as Presidents of the People's Republic of China from 1983 to the present, with Xi Jinping being the current president.
